title: mirb only: stack-buffer-overflow (OOB write) in main()
vulnerability_information:
Triggered in `7e28510` (7 April 2017) with `mirb` only.

`cat test013.rb | mirb`

```
==17976==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: stack-buffer-overflow on address 0x7fffeb477fb0 at pc 0x408c21 bp 0x7fffeb477a90 sp 0x7fffeb477a88
WRITE of size 1 at 0x7fffeb477fb0 thread T0
    #0 0x408c20 in main /root/mruby/mrbgems/mruby-bin-mirb/tools/mirb/mirb.c:466
    #1 0x7f96e4703b44 in __libc_start_main (/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6+0x21b44)
    #2 0x40aefc (/root/mruby/bin/mirb+0x40aefc)

Address 0x7fffeb477fb0 is located in stack of thread T0 at offset 1184 in frame
    #0 0x40549f in main /root/mruby/mrbgems/mruby-bin-mirb/tools/mirb/mirb.c:361

  This frame has 4 object(s):
    [32, 56) 'args'
    [96, 126) 'unexpected_end'
    [160, 1184) 'last_code_line' <== Memory access at offset 1184 overflows this variable
    [1216, 5312) 'ruby_code'
HINT: this may be a false positive if your program uses some custom stack unwind mechanism or swapcontext
      (longjmp and C++ exceptions *are* supported)
SUMMARY: AddressSanitizer: stack-buffer-overflow /root/mruby/mrbgems/mruby-bin-mirb/tools/mirb/mirb.c:466 main
```

activities.message:
Thank you for reporting this bug! This is an automated response to let you know that we've received your issue, and we'll process it as soon as possible.

Due to the large volume of reports we have received, it may take us up to two weeks to respond. Thank you for your patience!

Thank you for your report.

I couldn't reproduce this at `7e28510` or the current master (`0fb05eb`). I just get:
```
mirb - Embeddable Interactive Ruby Shell

input string too long
```
Neither ASAN nor valgrind report any issues.

Could you test this against the latest master, and let me know what your exact build environment is (operating system, compiler version, build flags, etc.)?

Debian 8 x64
gcc 4.9.2-10
CC=afl-gcc CFLAGS="-fsanitize=address" LDFLAGS="-fsanitize=address" make

With `6dd1a57` I'm able to trigger this again.

```
./mirb < test395.rb
mirb - Embeddable Interactive Ruby Shell

od -tx1 ./test395.rb
0000000 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30
*
0001760 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 30 0a
0002000
```

Also, do you still get a crash if you use the ordinary gcc instead of afl-gcc?

With `3123549` I see this:

```
~/mruby-no-asan/bin/mirb < test395.rb
mirb - Embeddable Interactive Ruby Shell

> Segmentation fault
```

```
valgrind -q ~/mruby-no-asan/bin/mirb < test395.rb
mirb - Embeddable Interactive Ruby Shell

> ==9568== Invalid write of size 1
==9568==    at 0x4C2C2A0: strcpy (vg_replace_strmem.c:458)
==9568==    by 0x402847: main (mirb.c:508)
==9568==  Address 0xfff001000 is not stack'd, malloc'd or (recently) free'd
==9568==
==9568==
==9568== Process terminating with default action of signal 11 (SIGSEGV)
==9568==  Access not within mapped region at address 0xFFF001000
==9568==    at 0x4C2C2A0: strcpy (vg_replace_strmem.c:458)
==9568==    by 0x402847: main (mirb.c:508)
==9568==  If you believe this happened as a result of a stack
==9568==  overflow in your program's main thread (unlikely but
==9568==  possible), you can try to increase the size of the
==9568==  main thread stack using the --main-stacksize= flag.
==9568==  The main thread stack size used in this run was 8388608.
Segmentation fault
```

```
(gdb) r < test395.rb
Starting program: /root/mruby-no-asan/bin/mirb < test395.rb
mirb - Embeddable Interactive Ruby Shell

>
Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
__strcpy_sse2_unaligned () at ../sysdeps/x86_64/multiarch/strcpy-sse2-unaligned.S:232
232     ../sysdeps/x86_64/multiarch/strcpy-sse2-unaligned.S: No such file or directory.
(gdb) bt
#0  __strcpy_sse2_unaligned () at ../sysdeps/x86_64/multiarch/strcpy-sse2-unaligned.S:232
#1  0x0000000000402848 in main (argc=1, argv=0x7fffffffec78) at /root/mruby-no-asan/mrbgems/mruby-bin-mirb/tools/mirb/mirb.c:508
```

```
dpkg --list | grep gcc
ii  gcc                            4:4.9.2-2                          amd64        GNU C compiler
ii  gcc-4.9                        4.9.2-10                           amd64        GNU C compiler
ii  gcc-4.9-base:amd64             4.9.2-10                           amd64        GCC, the GNU Compiler Collection (base package)
ii  libgcc-4.9-dev:amd64           4.9.2-10                           amd64        GCC support library (development files)
ii  libgcc1:amd64                  1:4.9.2-10                         amd64        GCC support library
```

```
gcc --version
gcc (Debian 4.9.2-10) 4.9.2
```

```
Linux debian-nyc3-07 3.16.0-4-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 3.16.39-1 (2016-12-30) x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

I have a few hundred testcases that exhibit this behavior.
I thought maybe it was due to memory pressure as my normal fuzzing boxen only have 512MB of RAM, but I just tested on a local Debian 8 x64 VM with 4GB of RAM and I get the same result.
I'm also able to reproduce this with the latest master (c0a4b1a) on Kali (a Debian clone) and gcc 6.3.0 20170124 (no asan).
Maybe you'll have more luck with this non-minimized testcase? test417.rb
I still can't reproduce. Are you sure you're building without AFL and without doing anything else unusual?

Yes. I am sure. There is nothing unsual going on, these are normal installs of Debian 8 x64 or a variant thereof (Kali). In the case of Kali, I just ran `git clone https://github.com/mruby/mruby` and then `cd mruby && make` and then ran it against my testcases. What platform are you testing on so that I can replicate it? I can give you SSH access to one of the Debian machines so you can see what I see.
I'm testing with OS X 10.12.4 (clang + ASAN) and Ubuntu 14.04 (gcc). I can try testing with other operating systems and compilers but I might not be able to get to that until next week.

Alright, I've deployed a 32-bit Ubuntu 16.10 VM and I'm able to replicate the same issue using the same testcases I provided. 

`gcc (Ubuntu 6.2.0-5ubuntu12) 6.2.0 20161005`
`Linux vultr.guest 4.8.0-45-generic #48-Ubuntu SMP Fri Mar 24 11:44:57 UTC 2017 i686 i686 i686 GNU/Linux`

```
root@vultr:~/mruby# valgrind -q bin/mirb < ../test395.rb
mirb - Embeddable Interactive Ruby Shell

> ==8046== Invalid write of size 1
==8046==    at 0x4031466: strcpy (in /usr/lib/valgrind/vgpreload_memcheck-x86-linux.so)
==8046==    by 0x8049EBD: main (mirb.c:508)
==8046==  Address 0xbeb6e000 is not stack'd, malloc'd or (recently) free'd
==8046==
==8046==
==8046== Process terminating with default action of signal 11 (SIGSEGV): dumping core
==8046==  Access not within mapped region at address 0xBEB6E000
==8046==    at 0x4031466: strcpy (in /usr/lib/valgrind/vgpreload_memcheck-x86-linux.so)
==8046==    by 0x8049EBD: main (mirb.c:508)
==8046==  If you believe this happened as a result of a stack
==8046==  overflow in your program's main thread (unlikely but
==8046==  possible), you can try to increase the size of the
==8046==  main thread stack using the --main-stacksize= flag.
==8046==  The main thread stack size used in this run was 8388608.
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

```
(gdb) r < ../test395.rb
Starting program: /root/mruby/bin/mirb < ../test395.rb
mirb - Embeddable Interactive Ruby Shell

>
Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
__strcpy_sse2 () at ../sysdeps/i386/i686/multiarch/strcpy-sse2.S:1745
1745    ../sysdeps/i386/i686/multiarch/strcpy-sse2.S: No such file or directory.
(gdb) bt
#0  __strcpy_sse2 () at ../sysdeps/i386/i686/multiarch/strcpy-sse2.S:1745
#1  0x08049ebe in main (argc=<error reading variable: Cannot access memory at address 0x30303030>, argv=0xbffff744) at /root/mruby/mrbgems/mruby-bin-mirb/tools/mirb/mirb.c:508
Backtrace stopped: previous frame inner to this frame (corrupt stack?)
```

This was just `git clone https://github.com/mruby/mruby && cd mruby && make`. No ASAN, no AFL, nothing special. I've attached the core dump.

Thanks for the additional information. I was eventually able to reproduce the problem. The key is that the libreadline headers must not be installed when MRuby is built. I've opened a pull request upstream: https://github.com/mruby/mruby/pull/3608

Thanks again for your report. This issue has been addressed upstream. The bug was only in mirb (and only when built in an unusual way) so this issue had no effect on Shopify Scripts.

Our next round of bounty decisions will take place within two weeks, so we'll be in touch with you again soon.
Thanks for helping improve the security of Shopify!
